review.title: Extracting Connected Concepts from Biomedical Texts using Fog Index
review.abstract: In this paper, we establish Fog Index (FI) as a text filter to locate the sentences in texts that contain connected biomedical concepts of interest. To do so, we have used 24 random papers each containing four pairs of connected concepts. For each pair, we categorize sentences based on whether they contain both, any or none of the concepts. We then use FI to measure difficulty of the sentences of each category and find that sentences containing both of the concepts have low readability. We rank sentences of a text according to their FI and select 30 percent of the most difficult sentences. We use an association matrix to track the most frequent pairs of concepts in them. This matrix reports that the first filter produces some pairs that hold almost no connections. To remove these unwanted pairs, we use the Equally Weighted Harmonic Mean of their Positive Predictive Value (PPV) and Sensitivity as a second filter. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our method.

sections.text: To find the sentences in texts that contain related biomedical concepts of interest, we used 24 random papers, each containing four pairs of related concepts. We categorized sentences for each pair based on whether they contain both or none of the concepts. We then used FI to measure the difficulty of sentences in each category and found that sentences that contain both concepts had low readability. We ranked sentences in a text according to their FI and selected 30 percent of the most difficult sentences. We used an association matrix to track the most common pairs of terms in them. This matrix reported that the first filter produced some pairs that had almost no connections. To remove these unwanted pairs, we used the Equally Weighted Harmonic Mean of Their Positive Predictive Value (PPV) and sensitivity as second filters. Experimental results show the effectiveness of our methodology. Keywords - computational gistics, textmining, Conceptability, Conceptability.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we report on the extraction of networked concepts from biomedical texts by evaluating the readability of texts. Text readability is determined by a metric called the Fog Index (FI). We curated 24 random works using four pairs of connected concepts as keywords and applied FI to them. Experimental results showed that sentences have low readability when they contain contiguous concepts. We selected 30 percent of the most difficult-to-read sentences and used an association matrix to locate the most common pairs of terms in them. To remove those pairs of terms that have a rather weak connection, we used the equally weighted harmonic mean of their positive predictive value and their sensitivity as second ranking filters. Results are supported by identifying almost all of the extracted concepts that are semantically connected by the UMLS semantic relationship network.
